column15: Show breaks between less comparable surveys Checkbox

column4: Gini coefficient
column5: Show data from both income and consumption surveys
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column2: Income or consumption share of the richest 10%
column4: Share of the richest 10%
column5: Show data from both income and consumption surveys
column7: This is the income or consumption of the richest decile (tenth of the population) as a share of total income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: Palma ratio
column5: Show data from both income and consumption surveys
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income or consumption received by the richest 10% divided by the share of the poorest 40%.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column2: Share of people in relative poverty
column4: Share in relative poverty
column5: Show data from both income and consumption surveys
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 50% of the median income or consumption.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column4: Mean log deviation
column5: Show data from both income and consumption surveys
column7: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal.
column8: Depending on the country and year, the data relates to disposable income or consumption per capita.

column2: Share of the richest decile in total income or consumption

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2022)
column5: The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality: it is the share of total income or consumption of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2022)
column5: % of population living in households with an income or consumption per person below 50% of the median.

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2022)
column5: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal. The measure is also referred to as 'Theil L' or 'GE(0)', in reference to the wider families of inequality measures to which the MLD belongs.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP)

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2022)
column5: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal. The measure is also referred to as 'Theil L' or 'GE(0)', in reference to the wider families of inequality measures to which the MLD belongs.
column7: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (PIP)

column4: World Bank Poverty and Inequality Platform (2022)
column5: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal. The measure is also referred to as 'Theil L' or 'GE(0)', in reference to the wider families of inequality measures to which the MLD belongs.

column5: The mean log deviation (MLD) is a measure of inequality. An MLD of zero indicates perfect equality and it takes on larger positive values as incomes become more unequal. The measure is also referred to as 'Theil L' or 'GE(0)', in reference to the wider families of inequality measures to which the MLD belongs.
